author: potuz
content: not if a 49% (or much less in fact) attacker is doing it. I think the question is not if the chain *could progress* if 51% of validators are honest but rather if it *will progress*. But yeah, it has become a matter of the definition of *advancing* by which we may not agree on the same one. For *livenes* that Jim mentions, the original Buterin-Griffith '17 add the word *plausible* which is key here. The main point of that is that if there's a network split or an outage, indeed the network can continue and when the split is resolved or the offline validators come online they can take from this continued chain and finalize it. So this protects the network from having less than 66% honest validators (say 51% as in the original comment) and zero dishonest. But it does not protect us from having 51% honest and 49% dishonest

author: eccentricexit
content:
I guess we can make progress by reframing the question:

In Gasper, if only 51% of validators are online the chain will eventually finalize as the inactivity leak automatically brings those to > 2/3.
Are there any other popular PoS algorithms with this property? I don't think so.

Extension: what does it take for Tendermint to start finalizing again, if suddenly 49% of validators are offline?

author: eccentricexit
content:
For context: I am asking this because I believed the Nakamoto Coefficient section of the latest Trail of Bits report for DARPA incorrectly placed Gasper along with all the other PoS algorithm as one that requires 2/3 of online validators.

But reading it with again with a fresh mind, I don't think they claimed that.
